title.rendered: Survivors of Sexual Assault and Interpersonal Violence

content.rendered:
If you are in immediate danger, call 9-1-1

If you have experienced a sexual assault or interpersonal violence, it is your choice how you proceed.  You are strongly encouraged to take actions that will preserve your ability to make future decisions. Seeking immediate medical attention and preserving evidence are two ways that you can make sure that your options do not become unintentionally limited. The University’s Title IX Coordinator and Campus Safety Office can help you as you navigate these choices and access medical and law enforcement resources.

 

Seek Medical Attention

The University encourages anyone who has experienced sexual assault or interpersonal violence to seek assistance from a medical provider as soon as possible after the incident. LA County has designated Sexual Assault Response Team (SART) Centers that can conduct sexual assault forensic examinations. The closest SART Center to ULV’s La Verne campus is Pomona Valley Hospital. Please be aware that while the University’s Student Health Center provides many services that may be important following an assault, they cannot conduct a sexual assault forensic examination. The University can facilitate connecting you with a SART as well as a Sexual Assault Victim’s Advocate, who can accompany you during your visit.

SART Centers
 

Preserve Evidence

It is important to take steps to preserve and collect evidence after a sexual assault or interpersonal violence incident as doing so preserves the full range of options available to you. In order to preserve evidence, it is recommended that you:
-do not wash your face or hands;
-do not shower or bathe;
-do not brush your teeth;
-do not change clothes;
-do not straighten up the area where the assault took place or wash bedding;
-do not dispose of clothes or other items that were present during the assault;
-do not use the restroom ; and
-seek medical and law enforcement support immediately
